title: JavaHashMap - Q0001
text: Which package contains the HashMap class?
explanation: The HashMap class is part of the java.util package.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0002
text: Which interface does HashMap implement?
explanation: HashMap implements the Map interface.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0003
text: Which data structure does HashMap use internally?

options.text: Array of buckets with linked lists or trees

explanation: HashMap uses an array of buckets internally, where each bucket may contain a linked list or a tree (since Java 8).

title: JavaHashMap - Q0004
text: What is the default initial capacity of a HashMap?
explanation: The default initial capacity of a HashMap is 16.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0005
text: What is the default load factor of a HashMap?
explanation: The default load factor of a HashMap is 0.75.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0006
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and null keys?

options.text: HashMap does not allow null keys
HashMap throws NullPointerException for null keys

explanation: HashMap allows one null key and multiple null values.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0007
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and null values?

options.text: HashMap allows only one null value
HashMap does not allow null values
HashMap throws exception for null values

explanation: HashMap allows multiple null values.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0008
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and duplicates?

options.text: HashMap does not allow duplicate keys

explanation: HashMap does not allow duplicate keys, but values can be duplicated.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0009
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and synchronization?
explanation: HashMap is not synchronized and is not thread-safe by default.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0010
text: Which of the following methods can be used to synchronize a HashMap?
explanation: The Collections.synchronizedMap() method returns a synchronized version of the map.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0011
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and performance?

options.text: HashMap provides O(1) average time for get and put
HashMap provides O(n) average time for get and put
HashMap provides O(log n) average time for get and put
HashMap provides O(n^2) average time for get and put

explanation: HashMap provides O(1) average time complexity for get and put operations.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0012
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and ordering?

options.text: HashMap does not maintain any order

explanation: HashMap does not maintain any specific order of keys or values.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0013
text: Which of the following is true about LinkedHashMap?
explanation: LinkedHashMap maintains insertion order of keys.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0014
text: Which of the following is true about TreeMap?

options.text: TreeMap maintains keys in sorted order

explanation: TreeMap maintains keys in sorted order according to their natural ordering or a comparator.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0015
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and capacity resizing?

options.text: HashMap doubles its capacity when load factor is exceeded

explanation: When the load factor threshold is exceeded, HashMap doubles its capacity.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0016
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and key uniqueness?

options.text: Keys can be null multiple times

explanation: Keys in a HashMap must be unique.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0017
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and values?
explanation: Values in a HashMap can be duplicated.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0018
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and fail-fast behavior?
explanation: HashMap iterators are fail-fast and throw ConcurrentModificationException if modified during iteration.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0019
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and entrySet()?

options.text: entrySet() returns a set view of key-value pairs

explanation: The entrySet() method returns a set view of key-value pairs in the map.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0020
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and keySet()?

options.text: keySet() returns a set view of keys
keySet() returns a collection of values
keySet() returns a map of entries

explanation: The keySet() method returns a set view of the keys contained in the map.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0021
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and values()?

options.text: values() returns a collection view of all values
values() returns a set of keys
values() returns a map of entries

explanation: The values() method returns a collection view of all values in the map.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0022
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and put()?

options.text: put() adds or replaces a key-value pair

explanation: The put() method adds a new key-value pair or replaces the value if the key already exists.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0023
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and putIfAbsent()?

options.text: putIfAbsent() adds a key-value pair only if the key is not already present

explanation: The putIfAbsent() method adds a key-value pair only if the key is not already present.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0024
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and get()?

options.text: get() returns the value associated with a key

explanation: The get() method returns the value associated with the specified key.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0025
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and getOrDefault()?

options.text: getOrDefault() returns a default value if the key is not found
getOrDefault() throws exception if key not found

explanation: The getOrDefault() method returns a default value if the key is not found in the map.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0026
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and remove()?

options.text: remove() deletes a key or key-value pair

explanation: The remove() method deletes a key or key-value pair from the map.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0027
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and replace()?

options.text: replace() updates the value for a given key

explanation: The replace() method updates the value for a given key if it exists.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0028
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and containsKey()?

options.text: containsKey() checks if a key exists
containsKey() checks if a value exists

explanation: The containsKey() method checks if a key exists in the map.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0029
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and containsValue()?

options.text: containsValue() checks if a value exists
containsValue() checks if a key exists

explanation: The containsValue() method checks if a value exists in the map.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0030
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and clear()?
explanation: The clear() method removes all key-value pairs from the map.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0031
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and size()?

options.text: size() returns the number of key-value pairs

explanation: The size() method returns the number of key-value pairs in the map.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0032
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and isEmpty()?

options.text: isEmpty() checks if the map has no entries

explanation: The isEmpty() method checks if the map contains no key-value pairs.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0033
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and compute()?

options.text: compute() updates a value using a remapping function

explanation: The compute() method updates a value using a remapping function for a given key.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0034
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and merge()?

options.text: merge() combines values for duplicate keys using a function

explanation: The merge() method combines values for duplicate keys using a specified function.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0035
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and replaceAll()?

options.text: replaceAll() replaces each value using a function

explanation: The replaceAll() method replaces each value using the provided function.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0036
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and forEach()?

options.text: forEach() performs an action for each key-value pair

explanation: The forEach() method performs the specified action for each key-value pair in the map.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0037
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and clone()?

options.text: clone() creates a shallow copy of the map
clone() creates a deep copy of the map

explanation: The clone() method creates a shallow copy of the HashMap.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0038
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and serialization?

options.text: HashMap cannot be written to a stream

explanation: HashMap implements Serializable, allowing it to be serialized.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0039
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and thread safety?
explanation: HashMap is not thread-safe; external synchronization is required.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0040
text: Which of the following is true about ConcurrentHashMap?
explanation: ConcurrentHashMap is thread-safe and does not allow null keys or values.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0041
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and fail-fast behavior?
explanation: HashMap iterators are fail-fast and throw ConcurrentModificationException if modified during iteration.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0042
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and computeIfAbsent()?

options.text: computeIfAbsent() computes a value if the key is not present

explanation: The computeIfAbsent() method computes and inserts a value if the key is not already present.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0043
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and computeIfPresent()?

options.text: computeIfPresent() updates a value if the key is present

explanation: The computeIfPresent() method updates a value using a remapping function if the key is present.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0044
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and entry iteration?

options.text: entrySet() allows iteration over key-value pairs

explanation: The entrySet() method allows iteration over key-value pairs.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0045
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and load factor?

options.text: Load factor determines when to resize the map
Load factor determines the number of keys
Load factor determines the hash code
Load factor determines the key type

explanation: The load factor determines when the map should resize to maintain performance.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0046
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and hash collisions?

options.text: Hash collisions are handled using linked lists or trees

explanation: Hash collisions are handled using linked lists or balanced trees (since Java 8).

title: JavaHashMap - Q0047
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and hash function?

options.text: HashMap uses hashCode() to compute bucket index
HashMap uses equals() to compute bucket index
HashMap uses toString() to compute bucket index
HashMap uses reference equality for bucket index

explanation: HashMap uses the hashCode() of the key to compute the bucket index.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0048
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and equals()?

options.text: equals() compares two maps for key-value equality

explanation: The equals() method compares two maps for key-value equality.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0049
text: Which of the following is true about HashMap and hashCode()?
explanation: The hashCode() of a HashMap depends on the hash codes of its entries.

title: JavaHashMap - Q0050
text: Which of the following best describes HashMap?

options.text: A hash-based map implementation storing key-value pairs

explanation: HashMap is a hash-based map implementation that stores key-value pairs.
